Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The Savannah River Scholars Program (SRSP) is increasing the number, quality and diversity of students graduating with bachelor degrees in chemistry, computer science, mathematics and physics. SRSP is offering sixteen scholarships per year, averaging $5,700 each for four consecutive years to academically talented and economically disadvantaged students. In addition to financial support, SRSP students are assigned a faculty mentor and a peer mentor. Undergraduate research is both encouraged and supported, and SRSP students attend monthly seminars on STEM research and graduate school and career opportunities. SRSP hosts a Career Connection panel composed of local industry leaders and alumni in relevant fields. Recruitment efforts focus on high school seniors planning to major in chemistry, computer science, mathematics or physics; ASU students enrolled in gateway STEM courses; part-time students; students showing interest in or engaged in undergraduate research in the targeted disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the Savannah River Scholars Program (SRSP) at Georgia Regents University was to increase the number, quality and diversity of students earning undergraduate degrees in chemistry, computer science, mathematics and physics. In addition, the program was designed to provide support for underrepresented and/or female students, provide support for part-time students making the transition to full-time study and encouraging participation in undergraduate research on campus. The program was, according to assessment results, recruit, retain and graduate students while creating a close-knit scientific community of student scholars and faculty.

     The SRSP has had a transformative effect through many events it has sponsored throughout the project. The SRSP established the following:

1. A series of monthly Science and Mathematics seminars which were attended by SRSP sholars and open to the entire university and the public. These events continue to be well attended and popular at the university.

2. An annual Career Connection event which involved inviting a panel of industry professionals for a panel discussion with students at the university. These events were attended by SRSP scholars and also open to the entire university and the public. Several students used these as networking opportunities and were subsequently offered internships as a direct result of connections made at these events.

3. The SRSP peer mentoring program represents collaboration with faculty in the Department of Political Science. A leadership practicum course was required of SRSP peer mentors; this course, offered through the political science department added a great deal of structure to the peer mentoring program and led to much higher levels of satisfaction among SRSP scholars.

     The SRSP also supported a diverse group of economically disadvantaged, academically talented students pursuing undergraduate degrees in the targeted disciplines including chemistry, computer science, mathematics and physics. Since first offering scholarships on fall 2011, the SRSP supported 39 undergraduats. Nineteen (19) have earned their degrees as of spring 2015. Many additional students who were supported by the program continue to work toward their degrees. 41% of the SRSP students were underrepresented and/or female students. (This figure is in contrast to the overall university population which is 34% female and 24% from underrepresented ethnicities.) Two-thirds of the SRSP scholars participated in faculty-led undergraduate research and 85% were retained through graduation. In addition, the project supported several part-time students who, because of SRSP financial support, were able to enroll full-time at the university.

     One unintended, but perhaps very telling outcome of the SRSP was that, according to assessments and exit interviews, every graduate left the university feeling like the belonged to a "science family". The importance of such cohesion has been well documented as a great indicatior of student success and satisfaction.
